title: How to Drink Vermouth

steps.headline: Try a white vermouth for a balance of sweet and bitter.
steps.description: White vermouth has a hint of sweet alongside a slight bitterness. Dry vermouth – a type of white vermouth – has a fresher flavor and noticeably less residual sugar than other white vermouths.

steps.headline: Try an Italian-style red vermouth for a sweeter and spicier taste.
steps.description: As all modern vermouths originate from white wine, red vermouth gets its distinct color and flavor from various aromatics. The traditional red vermouth has a sugar content of at least 14% (in contrast to dry vermouth’s less than 5%), yet also has an edge of bitterness and spice that adds to the sweet.

steps.headline: Ask a bartender or alcohol connoisseur for vermouth recommendations.
steps.description: A bottle of vermouth usually ranges between $15-$30 USD, with higher-quality vermouths costing a bit more. If you're on a budget, you can always ask for affordable options that are good for drinking plain.

steps.headline: Drink vermouth on the rocks.
steps.description: With such rich flavors, both red and white vermouths are delicious on their own. Put one large chunk or several small cubes of ice in a small glass or tumbler and add 3 fluid ounces (89 mL) of chilled or room-temperature vermouth. For dark red vermouths, garnish with an orange peel. For lighter vermouths, use a lemon slice or a skewered olive.

steps.headline: Add equal parts carbonated water for a vermouth spritzer.
steps.description: Some bars in Spain will provide a bottle of soda water when you order vermouth. Simply add equal parts vermouth and carbonated water for a refreshing twist.

steps.headline: Store the bottle of vermouth in a refrigerator.
steps.description: Vermouth is a type of wine, so it will turn to vinegar if left at room temperature. If properly chilled, a good bottle of vermouth can last 4 to 6 weeks after it’s opened.

steps.headline: Try a Gibson for a savory twist on a classic martini.
steps.description: Vermouth is commonly associated with   martinis or Manhattans. For a twist on a classic, pour 2.5 fluid ounces (74 mL) of gin and .5 fluid ounces (15 mL) of dry vermouth in a mixing glass with ice cubes. Stir well, then strain into a cocktail glass. Garnish with a cocktail onion to make a Gibson. Don’t let the terminology confuse you – a ‘dry’ cocktail is one with less (or no) dry vermouth, while a ‘wet’ cocktail is one with more dry vermouth. A ‘perfect’ is made with equal parts dry and sweet vermouth.

steps.headline: Add Scotch whiskey to make a Rob Roy.
steps.description: Mix 1  fl oz (30 mL) of sweet vermouth with 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of Scotch whiskey and 2 dashes of bitters in a shaker filled with ice. Stir, then strain into a martini glass and top with a lemon peel. For a sweeter garnish, use two skewered brandied cherries balanced on the cocktail glass.

steps.headline: Make an Italian-style negroni with sweet vermouth.
steps.description: In a cocktail shaker, combine equal parts sweet vermouth, Campari and gin. Pour over ice in a lowball glass and serve with an orange peel. A variation of the negroni called negroni sbagliato uses sparkling wine or Prosecco instead of gin for a bubbly fizz. Serve it in a champagne flute for extra class.

steps.headline: Use pineapple juice for a fruity Algonquin.
steps.description: Stir together 1.5 fluid ounces (44 mL)  of whiskey, .75 fluid ounces (22 mL) of dry vermouth, and .75 fluid ounces (22 mL) of pineapple juice with ice. Strain into a cocktail glass. Add a couple dashes of bitters to bring out the flavor even more.

steps.headline: Use both red and white vermouth to make a Bronx.
steps.description: The addition of sweet vermouth and orange juice make a Bronx less dry than a classic martini. Mix 2 fluid ounces (59 mL) of gin, .25  fl oz (7.4 mL) of dry vermouth, .25  fl oz (7.4 mL) of sweet vermouth, and 1  fl oz (30 mL) of orange juice to a shaker filled with ice. Shake, then strain into a cocktail glass and garnish with an orange slice. The Bronx is considered a more refreshing day drink than an evening cocktail, so enjoy it outside on a warm afternoon.
